title: Lagarde urges global policymakers to support economic growth - as it happened | Business | The Guardian
summary: us should cut rates - fed banker .
china 's transition faces `` bumps on the road ''
we support uk infrastructure spending - lagarde .
imf spotlights china , us policy and commodities .

documents.title: us should cut rates - fed banker
text: there has been much debate about whether the us federal reserve should raise interest rates this year , but one fed banker believes it should consider a cut instead .
minneapolis fed president narayana kocherlakota has said in a speech that low inflation gave the bank a huge opportunity to do more to revive the jobs market , reuters is reporting .
he said : given my current outlook , i believe that it would be appropriate to wait until 2017 to initiate liftoff and then raise the fed funds rate at about 2 percentage points per year .
to best fulfill its congressional mandates , the ( federal reserve open market committee ) should be considering reducing the target range for the fed funds rate , not increasing it .
the full speech is here .
on that note we 'll call a halt , so thanks for all your comments .
more from imf managing director christine lagarde , courtesy bloomberg : bloomberg tv ( @ bloombergtv ) lagarde is concerned janet yellen will raise rates too soon

documents.title: european shares edge higher
text: markets have moved ahead again , but it is not a particularly convincing rise .
more accurate , perhaps , to say they were barely changed .
there were few surprises from the bank of england and european central bank updates , while investors remained cautious ahead of the latest us federal reserve minutes .
commodity companies moved higher - glencore being an exception on continuing debt fears - as copper regained ground as an industry group forecast a deficit next year .
oil prices climbed on supply concerns , with brent crude currently more than 2 % better at $ 52.49 a barrel .

the final scores showed : the ftse 100 finished up 0.61 % or 38.47 points at 6374.82 germany 's dax is up 0.27 % at 9997.73 france 's cac closed up 0.2 % at 4676.74 italy 's ftse mib added 0.68 % at 22,156.74 spain 's ibex ended 0.11 % better at 10,181.2 in greece , the athens market dipped 0.3 % to 678.05 on wall street , the dow jones industrial average is up around 18 points or 0.11 % .
and the press conference is over .
imf

documents.title: we support uk infrastructure spending - lagarde
text: george osborne this week announced measures to boost infrastructure in britain .
is there enough fiscal space and is it a good time for britain to be doing that ?
we have come out publicly and supported infrastructure spending .
it is a win win for the economy .
it supports growth and activity in short term , puts people to work , improves medium to long term potential for growth , so absolutely yes .
if fiscal direction imposed by government is heading to stability and inspires confidence , it 's really an excellent choice .
could central banks now do more harm than good good [ given policy tools are now limited ] ?
impossible to answer : 188 central bandks round world .
clear central banks been a forefront of fighting great recesssion , thank goodness they were around , whether fed , ecb , bank of japan , bank of england .
we believe in certain regions , europe and japan , those monetary policies which have been helpful should continue because they have not reached their target .
imf been recommending a number of these policies for a while , but still gloomy outlook .
what can you do to get policymakers to heed the call ?
true we have been recommending demand , financial stability and structural reforms but not always applied .
some countries have done structural reforms , some done a little , some done nothing at all on infrastructure , we have seen some but not enough .

there is some hope on the call for international co-operation , when look at ttp , country commitment for cop 21 [ climate conference ] , however gloomy there are some interesting positive developments we had not expected .
would be good if 2010 reform of imf was ratified by us .
entering an era of longer crises [ and longer imf programmes ] ?
a matter we need to look at .
not suggesting we should have longer term imf programmes .
have seen difficulties with moving fast .
should look at programmes and see if they are fit for purpose .
will you pursue a second term as imf managing director ?
clearly this could be my last meeting , open to it not being but for membership to decide .
imf press conference

documents.title: china 's transition faces `` bumps on the road ''
text: china - what is your suggestion for policymakers in china , given the stock market fall and the devaluation of yuan ?
slowdown of growth in china was predictable and anticipated .
we believe it 's a good move .
to only grow at 6.8 % with a growth model not based on massive exports and capital projects but domestic demand is a good transition .
but it is a massive exercise and there will be bumps on the road , no transition can be made without any volatility .

here 's reuters take on lagarde 's early comments : international monetary fund chief christine lagarde urged global policymakers on thursday to support economic growth while also tackling financial risks stemming from the provision of easy money amid a rapidly changing and uncertain world . ''

lagarde , presenting a global policy agenda at the fund 's annual meeting in peru , said a recovery in the united states was broadly on track and a rise in u.s. interest rates is approaching '' and would tighten global funding conditions .
but she added that the slowing of economic activity in china and recent market volatility were having larger-than-expected spillovers across the global economy .
emerging economies , which have contributed the bulk of world growth in recent years , have been hit hard by a slump in commodity prices .

policymakers are increasingly grappling with difficult policy trade-offs , '' lagarde said , calling for a careful mix of policies to support economic demand , while also tackling financial risks and reforming economies to deliver future growth .

documents.title: greek position unchanged - imf
text: asked about the imf 's view on greece , lagarde said : on greece the position has not changed .
greece has requested support of imf , and any programme has to walk on two legs .
one : significant reforms embedded in legistlation , particularly on pension and bank governance .
two : a debt operation that renders greek debt sustainable .
capital economics ( @ capeconeurope ) # imf 's lagarde repeats view that # greek debt is unsustainable .
we agree .
major haircut , rather than minor restructuring , needed .
first question : is the slowdown in china and emerging markets already effecting economies elsewhere , as shown by recent german data ?
lagarde said the imf is still forecasting growth at 3.1 % , so recovering although decelerating , and is expected to improve in 2016 .
i would n't paint a dark but insist on policy to move from deceleration to something that is stronger .
also seeing rebalancing , where emerging economies are slowing down relative to what done so far .

documents.title: imf spotlights china , us policy and commodities
text: imf managing director christine lagarde is introducing the organisations annual meeting in peru .
she says policymakers should follow the example of the peruvian cuisine - which is a mix of best practices from around the world , refining and updating traditional recipes .
lagarde in peru /imf she says china , us monetary policy and commodities need to be managed .
policymakers must support growth , and international co-operation is more vital than ever .
they must reduce risks in an uncertain world .

meanwhile as news emerges that german prosecutors have mounted raids connected with the volkswagen emissions scandal , the us house committee on energy and commerce is about to quiz michael horn , vw 's us president and chief executive .
our live blog on the hearing is here : head of vw america testifies before us congress - live updates read more

documents.title: wall street slips at open
text: us shares have opened lower ahead of the release of the latest federal reserve minutes .
analysts will be looking carefully for signs of concern about emerging markets and its views on inflation .

jasper lawler , market analyst at cmc markets uk , said : if the minutes make it clear , like in recent speeches that fed members do not foresee much impact from an emerging market slowdown on the us economy , that could give the minutes a more hawkish tone .
inflation or lack thereof is the main domestic justification for not rising rates so any wording change that suggests the fed expects a slower return to the 2 % target would give off a dovish vibe .
the fed meeting obviously took place before the potentially game-changing latest jobs report so could be a little stale .
so after five days of gains , the dow jones industrial average has edged down 33 points or 0.2 % .
in europe , the ftse 100 , germany 's dax and the french cac are still marginally in positive territory .

december 's meeting of the european central bank is the most likely time for the central bank to consider expanding quantitative easing , said rbc european economist timo del carpio after today 's meeting : the ecb 's account of its september monetary policy meeting reveals a rather uneasy mood within the governing council .
a deteriorating inflation outlook , rising market volatility and renewed risks to global activity all appear to have precipitated a lively discussion last month .
however , there was little by way of a conclusive judgement on the implications for policy .
given the strong emphasis on the need to monitor incoming data , we think such a judgement may also fail to materialise at the october meeting as well .
instead , we continue to look to the december gathering as the most proximate opportunity for the ecb to cement expectations that qe will continue beyond september 2016 .
the european central bank has also released the minutes of its latest meeting today .
they 're staler than the bank of england 's fresh offering , as the ecb 's governing council met in early september .
but they show that the eurozone 's central bank is more concerned about emerging economies .

chief economist peter praet told the ecb that : challenges facing emerging market economies were clouding the global outlook and were unlikely to recede quickly although it was still premature to conclude whether these developments could have a lasting impact on euro area output and inflation , downside risks had intensified . ''
enrique diaz alvarez , chief risk officer and currency expert at financial services firm ebury , now believes uk interest rates will stay at record lows for longer .
surprisingly dovish minutes after an unsurprising decision to leave rates at 0.5 % .
only one dissenter asked for an immediate hike , and the committee focused on the prospects for even lower inflation since its last meeting .
the minutes also referenced a shortening lag between hiking rates and their impact on inflation- another hint that the bank of england feels it can afford to wait further before raising rates . ''
we now push our call for a first hike from february 2016 to the second quarter of the year .
this should generally be welcomed by uk businesses as it means the extraordinarily favourable environment of low rates should continue for quite a while longer . ''
the pound has fallen around half a cent against the us dollar since the bank of england decision was announced .
traders may be reacting to the line in the minutes about weaker inflation expectations , which suggest the bank is less willing to raise rates soon .
pound vs dollar , october 08 2015 reuters
david kern , chief economist of the british chambers of commerce , welcomed the bank 's decision to leave rates on hold .

a rate hike now would threaten the recovery , he believes , especially given the problems overseas : the uk recovery , although on course , is still fragile - it remains too reliant on consumer spending and is facing headwinds .
many major economies are experiencing difficulties that will inevitably increase the challenges for our exporters . ''

documents.title: ing predicts rate hike in h1 2016
text: here 's ing economist james knightley on today 's bank of england decision : the minutes to the meeting show that the mpc remains pretty upbeat on growth prospects with the economy expected to have expanded 0.6 % in 3q15 , which is around the trend rate of growth .

interestingly , they continue to downplay emerging market slowdown worries , stating that there had so far been few signs of a material effect on business and consumer confidence in the advanced economies '' .
knightley believes that wage growth will be crucial in determining when the boe will raise interest rates .
if financial market risk appetite continues to improve as well then we would suspect that ian mccafferty will not be alone in voting for a rate rise at the november mpc meeting .
we continue to look for the boe to raise rates in the first half of 2016 , well ahead of the 4q16 [ fourth quarter ] move financial markets are currently pricing .
the bank of england 's economists predict that the uk economy grew by 0.6 % in the third quarter of this year .
that 's a dip on the second quarter , when gdp rose by 0.7 % , but not a significant drop .
yesterday , the niesr thinktank predicted growth of 0.5 % in q3 .
some instant reaction to today 's bank minutes : duncan weldon ( @ duncanweldon ) boe minutes , like the new imf forecasts , are pretty sanguine on chinese growth .
world first ( @ world first ) v much as expected and little new in the minutes .
key will be medium term inflation expectations in next month 's qir katie martin ( @ katie martin fx ) greece gets a paltry single mention in the boe minutes .
# crisisover
the words china '' and chinese '' crop up more than 10 times in the minutes , showing that the boe is paying close attention to its economy .
mike van dulken ( @ accendo mike ) boe mins word/term count : china/chinese x 11 , oil x 6 , emerging market x 11 , united states x 8 , commodity x 2 , fomc & ecb x 3 , deflation x 0
you can see the minutes online here ( pdf ) .

the bank of england minutes show that policymakers discussed the slowdown in emerging markets , but they are n't panicking about china yet : outside the advanced economies , a continued slowdown in emerging market growth remained evident , most notably in brazil and russia .

despite increased concern about growth prospects in china and the associated reduction and volatility in risky asset prices , chinese activity indicators to date had been steady and the authorities had implemented a range of stimulatory policy initiatives .

although there remained a risk that emerging market prospects might deteriorate further , there had so far been few signs of a material effect on business and consumer confidence in the advanced economies .

documents.title: bank of england : inflation outlook is weaker
text: the bank of england now believes that inflation will rise more slowly than it expected two months ago .
inflation is currently zero , according to the latest data .
and today 's minutes show that the boe believes cheap energy costs will prevent it rising quickly .
today 's minutes say : the near-term outlook for cpi inflation appeared slightly weaker than at the time of the august inflation report , in part reflecting the further decline in the oil price .
cpi inflation was likely to remain close to zero before up around the turn of the year .
but it now appeared likely to remain below 1 % until spring 2016 .
and that means less pressure to raise interest rates soon .
igsquawk ( @ igsquawk ) boe sees inflation staying below 1 % until spring 2016
the bank of england says there is a range of views '' among members of the monetary policy committee over the inflation outlook .
but only one member , ian mccafferty , wanted to raise rates at this month 's meeting .

ian mccafferty preferred to increase bank rate by 25 basis points , given his view that building domestic cost pressures were likely to come to outweigh the dampening influence of the appreciation of sterling , causing inflation to overshoot the 2 % target in the medium term .
the bank adds that interest rate are expected to rise more gradually '' than in the past , and to a lower level .
but such guidance , however , is an expectation and not a promise : the path that bank rate will actually follow over the next few years will depend on economic circumstances .
the boe has also left its quantitative easing programme unchanged , at £ 375bn .
bank of england ( @ bankofengland ) bank of england maintains # bankrate at 0.5 % and the size of the asset purchase programme at £ 375 billion

documents.title: bank of england leaves interest rates unchanged ( again )
text: here we go the bank of england has voted to leave interest rates unchanged at 0.5 % , by 8 votes to 1 .
that means borrowing costs have been stuck at their record low since march 2009 .
at noon sharp , the bank of england will announce its decision on monetary policy , and release the minutes of this week 's meeting .
there 's no realistic chance they 'll raise interest rates today .
but the monetary policy committee could be split again , if ian mccafferty continues to lobby for a hike .
jeremy cook of world first believes rates wo n't be raised until next spring , or summer .

he 's tweeted a few thoughts : world first ( @ world first ) my # boe thoughts with 30 mins to go 1 ) let 's make no bones about it , rates are not moving higher for at least 6/9 months world first ( @ world first ) 2 ) mccafferty to still vote for a hike because of his focus on wage driven infaltion and the need to normalise soon to ensure a gradual path world first ( @ world first ) 3 ) sterling assets and rate expectations have slipped too far and expect gbp to rebuild .
i like eurgbp to underperform in q4 world first ( @ world first ) 4 ) keys moving forward remain how much deflation from em/china impacts in coming months vs base effects of lower oil prices

the economist intelligence unit believes the german economy remains quite solid , despite the big drop in exports and imports in august : here 's their reasoning : the eiu europe ( @ theeiu europe ) 1/4 the m-o-m fall in german exports is the biggest since the financial crisis the eiu europe ( @ theeiu europe ) 2/4 but we think risks should n't be overstated-other sentiment indicators suggest reasonable near-term growth outlook the eiu europe ( @ theeiu europe ) 3/4 holiday impact means should n't read too much into one month 's data # germany the eiu europe ( @ theeiu europe ) 4/4 impact of em slowdown on german exports has been visible for a while , key remains us , non-ez eu and spain

documents.title: ab inbev urges sab shareholders to speak up over takeover bid
text: brewing giant anheuser-busch inbev uk is getting increasingly irked with sabmiller 's refusal to accept its £ 65bn takeover offer .
ab inbev just released a new statement to the city , saying it is surprised '' that sab says the latest offer , at £ 42.15 per share , still very substantially undervalues '' it .
carlos brito , ab inbev 's ceo , insists shareholders are being offered a good deal , and suggests they make their view known to sab 's management .
notwithstanding our good faith efforts , the board of sabmiller has refused to meaningfully engage with us .
our proposal creates significant value for everybody .
how long will it be before shareholders see a value of over £ 42 in the absence of an offer from ab inbev ?

if shareholders agree that we should be in proper discussions , they should voice their views and should not allow the board of sabmiller to frustrate this process and let this opportunity slip away . ''
sab 's shares were worth around £ 30 before ab inbev made its first approach , and are now trading around £ 36 .
jamie nimmo ( @ jamienimmo63 ) ab inbev statement suggests it 's becoming increasingly hostile # sab

documents.title: greek trade slumps in august
text: new trade data from greece shows that imports and exports both fell sharply in august , as capital controls continued to grip the economy .
imports slumped by 8.9 % year-on-year , according to stats body elstat , from €3.3bn to €3bn .
exports also contracted by 8.9 % , from €2.08bn to €1.89bn .
that includes a 22 % fall in exports to countries outside the eu .

turquoise = eu exports ; light blue = other exports ; purple = eu imports ; yellow = other imports greek firms have warned that the restrictions on capital flow imposed in july are hurting the economy very badly .
capital controls make it hard to buy raw materials from overseas , or sell finished goods to overseas buyers .
macropolis ( @ macropolis gr ) # greece aug trade deficit -8.8 % to €1.12 bln , exports -8.9 % , imports -8.9 % .
( elstat ) # economy elstat also reported that the greek unemployment rate was unchanged in july , at 25 % .
greek unemployment rate , july 2015
curiously , deutsche bank shares are now rallying in frankfurt , reversing their early selloff .
that 's quite a turnaround , given they were expected to shed 10 % after it announced its €6bn loss .
investors may be reassured that joint-ceo john cryan is getting to grips with deutsche 's problems , by cutting jobs and admitting that some assets are overvalued .
frances coppola ( @ frances coppola ) why is everyone so bothered about deutsche writing down investments that we all knew were overvalued ?
shares , eh ?
mike bird ( @ birdyword ) deutsche bank down 7 % after-hours in new york , down 2.5 % at the open in germany , now up 1 % because ¯\ ( ツ ) /¯

international monetary fund managing director christine lagarde ( l ) and world bank president jim yong kim discuss climate change in lima jaffe/afp/getty images the emerging market slowdown will be high on the agenda as global policymakers gather in lima for the latest annual meeting of the international monetary fund and the world bank .

my colleague heather stewart explains : brazil and russia are in recession , china is slowing sharply , and a string of other emerging countries , including turkey and venezuela , look vulnerable to the combination of falling commodity prices and a strengthening dollar .
finance ministers will discuss how to prevent this weakness from spiralling into a full-blown financial crisis .
other key themes include tax avoidance , greece , and the impact of a us interest rate hike .
heather 's preview of the meeting has more details : imf : china slump and tax avoidance to dominate peru talks read more

documents.title: volkswagen to be grilled over emissions scandal
text: it 's not a great day for europe 's powerhouse economy .
and it could get worse , when vw 's us boss testifies at capitol hill this afternoon ( from 3pm bst ) .
michael horn will apologise for the emissions scandal , and tell congress that he was aware of the problem last year , according to his prepared testimony .

head of vw in us will tell congress he knew of emissions rigging in early 2014 read more caroline hyde ( @ carolinehydetv ) brutal morning 4 german business dismal data as exports slump most since '09 , # deutschebank post massive loss , vw us showdown
shares in deutsche bank have slid by 2.5 % in early trading .
that 's a smaller fall than feared , as traders digest the news that it will lose €6bn in the third quarter of 2015 , its biggest quarterly loss in at least a decade .
my colleague julia kollewe explains : in a late night announcement that shocked analysts , germany 's biggest bank blamed huge impairment charges of €5.8bn for the unexpected losses .
forecasts had been for profits of around €1bn .
the charges are related to higher capital requirements for deutsche 's investment bank and the reduced value of its postbank division , which is up for sale .
deutsche also took a €600m writedown on the value of its 20 % stake in china 's hua xia bank , which it also wants to offload .
it bought the stake in 2005 and it is now worth about $ 3.5bn .
deutsche bank shocks with warning of €6bn losses read more
the disappointing german trade data is pushing down shares in frankfurt .
germany 's dax has shed 51 points , or 0.5 % , in early trading .
big exporters such as pharmaceuticals firm bayer and chemicals giant basf are among the fallers .
another sign that china 's rebalancing is hurting germany : capital economics ( @ capeconeurope ) august # german trade figs show further slowdown in export growth .
# china slowdown offsetting boost from lower euro .
pau morilla-giner , chief investment officer at london & capital asset management , says the weak economic data from germany in august is a worry .
speaking on bloomberg tv now , he 's explaining that germany is more exposed to the global economy than its neighbours : germany is the canary in the coalmine for europe .

documents.title: economist : germany suffering from chinese weakness
text: holger sandte , chief european economist at nordea , agrees that germany is being buffeted by problems in emerging markets : this is a strong fall , the kind you do n't see every day .
weakness in china , brazil , russia and other markets is having an impact . ''
( quote via reuters )
it 's worth noting that august can be a quieter month for trade , given the summer holidays in europe .
but still , a 5 % drop in exports is certainly unusual .
tv the slide in german exports in august is bad news for the european economy , argues bloomberg tv 's hans nichols .
he warns that the eurozone core is looking shaky .
everyone 's been looking to germany to be the engine of growth in the eurozone .
france is flat , and germany looks like it may be flatlining . ''

hans also points out that these figures wo n't capture the impact of the volkswagen diesel emissions scandal on germany 's economy : that 's not only a psychological blow but a real economic outlook blow too . ''
so september 's data , due in a month 's time , could be weak too

documents.title: german exports slump by 5.2 % in august
text: germany has just suffered its biggest fall in exports since the dark days of the financial crisis .
it 's another sign that storm clouds are gathering over the eurozone 's largest economy .
exports slumped by 5.2 % in august compared to july , according to new data from the federal statistics office .
it suggests the problems in china , and the wider slowdown in other emerging markets , is hitting demand for german products overseas .
economists had only expected a 0.9 % fall .
imports fell by 3.1 % , indicating domestic demand is weakening too .
lemasabachthani ( @ lemasabachthani ) german august exports fall 5.2 % in month ; est .
0.9 % drop that means germany 's trade surplus shrank to €15.3bn , from €25bn in july .
on an annual basis , exports were still 5 % higher than in august 2014 .

but demand does appear to have tailed off over the summer : it 's the third piece of bad economic data from germany this week , following disappointing falls in factory orders and industrial production during august .

add in the volkswagen scandal , and the problems emerging at deutsche bank , and the problems are piling up dick darlington ( @ darlington dick ) german exports slump most since 2009 recession in sign of risks ( bbg )

documents.title: the agenda : big day for central banks
text: the canary wharf business district and the city of london /bloomberg via getty images good morning , and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy , the financial markets , the eurozone and business .
it 's a busy day for central banks .
over in london , the bank of england will release its latest interest rate decision , and the minutes of the meeting , at noon bst .
the boe is likely to leave interest rates on hold again .
but the minutes will be closely watched , for signs that policymakers are more concerned over the global economy .
jasper lawler of cmc markets sets the scene : given the very low rates of inflation , the bank of england should keep rates on hold at a record low 0.5 % .
the meeting minutes , which under the new format are released simultaneously , are expected to show the mpc again voted 8-1 to leave rates unchanged given global uncertainty .
there 's an outside chance that the recent jump in uk wage growth could compel martin weale to join ian mccafferty in voting for a rate rise .
thirty minutes later , the european central bank releases the minutes of its last meeting in september .
ecb chief economist peter praet is giving a speech around the same time .
and at 7pm bst , the federal reserve release their own minutes .
they could also shift the markets , given the constant chatter over when the fed might raise rates .
bank of england governor mark carney is actually in lima today for the international monetary fund 's annual meeting .
he 's appearing on a panel from 7pm bst , along with imf md christine lagarde and brazilian finance minister joaquim levy .
we should hear from lagarde at 3pm bst , when she briefs the press .
also coming up today us politicians in washington are preparing to grill michael horn , president and chief executive of volkswagen group of america , over the emissions scandal .
that starts at 3pm bst ( 10am local time ) .
and we 'll be watching deutsche bank , after the german bank stunned investors last night by announcing it expects a $ 7bn loss this quarter , due to problems at its corporate banking unit .

shares are probably going to take a pasting when frankfurt opens bloomberg business ( @ business ) deutsche bank expects third-quarter loss of €6.2 billion ( $ 7 billion ) and may scrap dividend we 'll be tracking all the main events through the day

bulletin.text: IMF praises George Osborne's infrastructure plans; Britain's central bank leaves borrowing costs at their record low again.
Latest: Bank of England interest rate decision.
Only McCafferty votes for a hike.
Bank: Cheap oil keeping inflation low.
